channel.title: [317] Resizable, Faster, and better all around
channel.description:
I am upgrading the 317 client and I wish to release it to everyone, I will post my bigger updates here:
[b][i]Updates (log):[/i] [/b]
New timing system, New image buffer system, New closing/cleanup system, Countless 'tuneups', Added [b][u]resizing with scaling[/u][/b], Fixed crash while unpacking interfaces, Removed RSA login packet encryption (you can re-add it later if you want), Disabled JAGGRAB (you can re-add it later if you want), Fixed little 'smudges' in the client (loading bar offsets, error handling, text display, etc...), Changed cache directory to ./cache/ for my convience (you can change it later if you want)
And more to come!
[b][i]Download links:[/i][/b]
Cache included (317 or whatever the MoparScape client provides): 1. http://www.mediafire.com/download.php?n1tjqhhtmiz No cache included 1. http://www.mediafire.com/download.php?zjzvzdndzy5
Please report broken link(s), I will post mirrors on request.
[b][i]Future additions (plans):[/i][/b]
JOGL, Newest RS2 client processing system, Newest RS2 client compatability, Newest RS2 client graphics system (one buffer for all graphics instead of having one for each section (317 has about 10)), A loader to go along with this (and maybe even a server (with ondemand and jaggrab!))
And yes..., more to come.
Please request anything you would suggest to be a good update (not just for you, but for everyone), also if you wish to rant about this...go do it somewhere else, I don't care (I have no idea why you would wan't to rant about this anyway...).
Pics: [img]http://img69.imageshack.us/img69/2857/39952174.png[/img] [img]http://img69.imageshack.us/img69/4734/86406442.png[/img] [img]http://img265.imageshack.us/img265/2762/64901403.png[/img] [img]http://img29.imageshack.us/img29/9033/13865274.png[/img] [img]http://img12.imageshack.us/img12/9743/88325538.png[/img] [img]http://img337.imageshack.us/img337/9035/26803130.png[/img]

item.title: [317] Resizable, Faster, and better all around
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:30, topic:314962”]The granulatiry of the result MAY depend on the underlying operating system. I am neither spamming nor trolling. Just merely showing you how FUCKING stupid the resize is, and how LITTLE you know about the client methods. Sware to god, the LEAST you could do when resizing is at least shade the surroinding pixels so it doesn’t look absolutely atrocious.

EDIT: Who the hell are you calling a punk?

  1. You’ve been here what? 1 day? Only 15 posts. You have no idea how this community works. EXPECT TO HAVE YOUR VIEWS FUCKED.
  2. According to your profile, you’re 39 years old… REALLY??? damn near 40, messing with RSPS? Don’t you have a life? I mean, teens, that’s understandable. 20’s, you’ve had enough time and exposure that you would be quite knowledgable. 30, that’s kind of pushing it. I think mitb is somewhere around 30, but since he owns the forums, he has an excuse. but 40??? COME ON!!![/quote]

Finally, someone who has the balls to tell em how it is. I have been trying to be nice, i got people watching me :|. Oh well though, but yea, as he said. Expect some critisism and some people to dought you. I requote this peice

“1. You’ve been here what? 1 day? Only 15 posts. You have no idea how this community works. EXPECT TO HAVE YOUR VIEWS FUCKED.”
Your lucky you didnt get the “NOOB” factor shot at you. I will end it here, and leave this topic, but i WILL be watching this, to see if you deserve the “NOOB” factor.

Read full topic
item.source: [317] Resizable, Faster, and better all around

item.title: [317] Resizable, Faster, and better all around
item.dc:creator: @virtualize virtualize
item.description:
@virtualize wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:30, topic:314962”][quote author=virtualize link=topic=411412.msg3035536#msg3035536 date=1258723750]

  1. Why resize the client? The gameframe looks horrible, the resolution is shit, completely fucked up, you see where i’m going with this.
  2. [quote author=“Java API”]
    currentTimeMillis

public static long currentTimeMillis()

Returns the current time in milliseconds. Note that while the unit of time of the return value is a millisecond, the granularity of the value depends on the underlying operating system and may be larger. For example, many operating systems measure time in units of tens of milliseconds.

See the description of the class Date for a discussion of slight discrepancies that may arise between "computer time" and coordinated universal time (UTC).

Returns:
    the difference, measured in milliseconds, between the current time and midnight, January 1, 1970 UTC.
See Also:
    Date

nanoTime

public static long nanoTime()

Returns the current value of the most precise available system timer, in nanoseconds.

This method can only be used to measure elapsed time and is not related to any other notion of system or wall-clock time. The value returned represents nanoseconds since some fixed but arbitrary time (perhaps in the future, so values may be negative). This method provides nanosecond precision, but not necessarily nanosecond accuracy. No guarantees are made about how frequently values change. Differences in successive calls that span greater than approximately 292 years (263 nanoseconds) will not accurately compute elapsed time due to numerical overflow.

For example, to measure how long some code takes to execute:

   long startTime = System.nanoTime();
   // ... the code being measured ...
   long estimatedTime = System.nanoTime() - startTime;
 

Returns:
    The current value of the system timer, in nanoseconds.
Since:
    1.5[/quote]
  1. I tried both of your codes. Both gave me the same answer(approximately. Rounded to make space), so i believe you sir are the one who is misinformed.

Well that must be because of your os, “depends on the underlying operating system.”

Also, the reason I made it scale like i did is because if i use the other method resizes it then it messes with my coordination. If you don’t like it then don’t worry about it. I don’t need people on my thread spamming and trolling around. I don’t care for your opinion. Get the hint, punk?[br][br][size=1]Posted on: November 20, 2009, 07:31:58 am[/size][hr][quote author=Miss Silabsoft link=topic=411412.msg3035376#msg3035376 date=1258698061]

no i just didint have time, i just got back form coon hunting ;)[br][br][size=1]Posted on: November 19, 2009, 11:02:15 pm[/size][hr][quote author=CoonHunter link=topic=411412.msg3034941#msg3034941 date=1258663608]
@virtualize - If you cant accept the fact, that your not gonna get 100% good comments, then gtfo rsps communities, becuase it is the base for improvement, and just being plain stupid.

@TOPIC - I acually think this is one of the worst idea’s i have ever seen, your doing nothing but streching the damn thing. Try converting it to a fullscreen, and then we will talk. Stuff like this is not needed.

Please stop trolling my topic. I don’t care about your foolish opinion.

@Silabsoft, nano time is better because System.currentTimeMillis uses 10 millisecond precision, nano time uses extremely high precision. System.currentTimeMillis was ment to be used to aquire the current system time which can be changed by the user at any given time. If you read the System.nanoTime documention it mentions that it is primarly used to measure time from point a to point b. Not the case of System.currentTimeMillis[br][br][size=1]Posted on: November 19, 2009, 11:05:21 pm[/size][hr]Soon as i get the time i am going to implement this system:


final class proc
{
	static long method1980()
	{
		return aLong3769;
	}

	static int method1979(int i, int k)
	{
		long l = 0xf4240L * (long) k;
		sleep((long) i);
		aLong3769 += calc();
		if (aLong3768 > aLong3769)
		{
			sleep((aLong3768 - aLong3769) / 1000000L);
			aLong3770 += aLong3768 - aLong3769;
			aLong3769 += aLong3768 - aLong3769;
			aLong3768 += l;
			return 1;
		}
		int i1 = 0;
		do
		{
			aLong3768 += l;
			++i1;
		}
		while (i1 < 10 && aLong3768 < aLong3769);
		if (aLong3769 > aLong3768)
			aLong3768 = aLong3769;

		return i1;
	}

	private static long calc()
	{
		long l = System.nanoTime();
		{
			long l1 = l - aLong3770;
			aLong3770 = l;
			if (l1 > -5000000000L && l1 < 5000000000L)
			{
				aLongArray3771[anInt3772] = l1;
				anInt3772 = (anInt3772 + 1) % 10;
				if (anInt3773 < 1)
					anInt3773++;

			}
		}
		l = 0L;
		for (int j = 1; j <= anInt3773; ++j)
			l += aLongArray3771[(10 + anInt3772 - j) % 10];

		return l / (long) anInt3773;
	}

	static void push()
	{
		if (aLong3768 > aLong3769)
			aLong3769 += aLong3768 - aLong3769;

		aLong3770 = 0L;
	}

	private static void sleep(long l)
	{
		if (l < 1L)
			return;

		if (l % 10L == 0L)
		{
			try
			{
				Thread.sleep(l - 1L);
			}
			catch (InterruptedException n) { }
			try
			{
				Thread.sleep(1L);
			}
			catch (InterruptedException n) { }
			return;
		}
		try
		{
			Thread.sleep(l);
		}
		catch (InterruptedException n) { }
	}

	private static int anInt3772;
	private static int anInt3773;
	private static long aLong3768;
	private static long aLong3769;
	private static long aLong3770;
	private static long[] aLongArray3771;

	static
	{
		anInt3773 = 1;
		aLongArray3771 = new long[10];
		aLong3769 = System.nanoTime();
		aLong3768 = System.nanoTime();
	}
}

Which is not fully refactored from the rs2 client, but I havent rethought of the proper names since i did this last around 4 months ago.
[/quote]

The client does not use current system time for anything accurate so to change that without a performance increase seems to be rather redundant. If the client required the current system time for something very accurate the nanosecond would be well worth it.
[/quote]
The FPS processor uses it mainly to tell how much time has passed…[br][br][size=1]Posted on: November 20, 2009, 07:41:12 am[/size][hr]Take for instance, the flame processor.

long l1 = System.currentTimeMillis();
int k = (int)(l1 - l) / 10 - j;
j = 40 - k;
if (j < 5)
	j = 5;
i = 0;
l = l1;

if you where to set the time back idk… a month? This is what the math would look like:

//l = 2592000000 (1 month 30 days)
long l1 = 0;
int k = (int)(0 - 2592000000) / 10 - j;
j = 40 - k;
if (j < 5)
	j = 5;
i = 0;
l = l1;

so this would sleep for about 5 months lol
[/quote]

The granulatiry of the result MAY depend on the underlying operating system. I am neither spamming nor trolling. Just merely showing you how FUCKING stupid the resize is, and how LITTLE you know about the client methods. Sware to god, the LEAST you could do when resizing is at least shade the surroinding pixels so it doesn’t look absolutely atrocious.

EDIT: Who the hell are you calling a punk?

  1. You’ve been here what? 1 day? Only 15 posts. You have no idea how this community works. EXPECT TO HAVE YOUR VIEWS FUCKED.
  2. According to your profile, you’re 39 years old… REALLY??? damn near 40, messing with RSPS? Don’t you have a life? I mean, teens, that’s understandable. 20’s, you’ve had enough time and exposure that you would be quite knowledgable. 30, that’s kind of pushing it. I think mitb is somewhere around 30, but since he owns the forums, he has an excuse. but 40??? COME ON!!![/quote]
    Don’t lie fool, your spamming and trolling my topic, please leave. I am not 39 you ignorant bastard. Notice 1970 is the beggining of the epoch? i put it in there as a joke…im 14

Read full topic
item.source: [317] Resizable, Faster, and better all around

		{
			try
			{

i = 0;
l = l1;

if you where to set the time back idk… a month? This is what the math would look like:

//l = 2592000000 (1 month 30 days)
long l1 = 0;
int k = (int)(0 - 2592000000) / 10 - j;
j = 40 - k;
if (j < 5)
	j = 5;
i = 0;
l = l1;

so this would sleep for about 5 months lol[/quote]

The granulatiry of the result MAY depend on the underlying operating system. I am neither spamming nor trolling. Just merely showing you how FUCKING stupid the resize is, and how LITTLE you know about the client methods. Sware to god, the LEAST you could do when resizing is at least shade the surroinding pixels so it doesn’t look absolutely atrocious.

EDIT: Who the hell are you calling a punk?

  1. You’ve been here what? 1 day? Only 15 posts. You have no idea how this community works. EXPECT TO HAVE YOUR VIEWS FUCKED.
  2. According to your profile, you’re 39 years old… REALLY??? damn near 40, messing with RSPS? Don’t you have a life? I mean, teens, that’s understandable. 20’s, you’ve had enough time and exposure that you would be quite knowledgable. 30, that’s kind of pushing it. I think mitb is somewhere around 30, but since he owns the forums, he has an excuse. but 40??? COME ON!!!

Read full topic

Rofl. i dont see why everyone is so sceptical of this guy, he seems like he knows what hes on about tbh

item.title: [317] Resizable, Faster, and better all around
item.dc:creator: @virtualize virtualize
item.description:
@virtualize wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:27, topic:314962”]1. Why resize the client? The gameframe looks horrible, the resolution is shit, completely fucked up, you see where i’m going with this.
2. [quote author=“Java API”]
currentTimeMillis

public static long currentTimeMillis()

Returns the current time in milliseconds. Note that while the unit of time of the return value is a millisecond, the granularity of the value depends on the underlying operating system and may be larger. For example, many operating systems measure time in units of tens of milliseconds.

See the description of the class Date for a discussion of slight discrepancies that may arise between "computer time" and coordinated universal time (UTC).

Returns:
    the difference, measured in milliseconds, between the current time and midnight, January 1, 1970 UTC.
See Also:
    Date

[/quote]

nanoTime

public static long nanoTime()

Returns the current value of the most precise available system timer, in nanoseconds.

This method can only be used to measure elapsed time and is not related to any other notion of system or wall-clock time. The value returned represents nanoseconds since some fixed but arbitrary time (perhaps in the future, so values may be negative). This method provides nanosecond precision, but not necessarily nanosecond accuracy. No guarantees are made about how frequently values change. Differences in successive calls that span greater than approximately 292 years (263 nanoseconds) will not accurately compute elapsed time due to numerical overflow.

For example, to measure how long some code takes to execute:

   long startTime = System.nanoTime();
   // ... the code being measured ...
   long estimatedTime = System.nanoTime() - startTime;
 

Returns:
    The current value of the system timer, in nanoseconds.
Since:
    1.5[/quote]
  1. I tried both of your codes. Both gave me the same answer(approximately. Rounded to make space), so i believe you sir are the one who is misinformed.[/quote]
    Well that must be because of your os, “depends on the underlying operating system.”

Also, the reason I made it scale like i did is because if i use the other method resizes it then it messes with my coordination. If you don’t like it then don’t worry about it. I don’t need people on my thread spamming and trolling around. I don’t care for your opinion. Get the hint, punk?[br][br][size=1]Posted on: November 20, 2009, 07:31:58 am[/size][hr][quote=“Miss Silabsoft, post:26, topic:314962”][quote author=virtualize link=topic=411412.msg3035319#msg3035319 date=1258692993]
no i just didint have time, i just got back form coon hunting ;)[br][br][size=1]Posted on: November 19, 2009, 11:02:15 pm[/size][hr][quote author=CoonHunter link=topic=411412.msg3034941#msg3034941 date=1258663608]
@virtualize - If you cant accept the fact, that your not gonna get 100% good comments, then gtfo rsps communities, becuase it is the base for improvement, and just being plain stupid.

@TOPIC - I acually think this is one of the worst idea’s i have ever seen, your doing nothing but streching the damn thing. Try converting it to a fullscreen, and then we will talk. Stuff like this is not needed.

Please stop trolling my topic. I don’t care about your foolish opinion.

@Silabsoft, nano time is better because System.currentTimeMillis uses 10 millisecond precision, nano time uses extremely high precision. System.currentTimeMillis was ment to be used to aquire the current system time which can be changed by the user at any given time. If you read the System.nanoTime documention it mentions that it is primarly used to measure time from point a to point b. Not the case of System.currentTimeMillis[br][br][size=1]Posted on: November 19, 2009, 11:05:21 pm[/size][hr]Soon as i get the time i am going to implement this system:


final class proc
{
	static long method1980()
	{
		return aLong3769;
	}

	static int method1979(int i, int k)
	{
		long l = 0xf4240L * (long) k;
		sleep((long) i);
		aLong3769 += calc();
		if (aLong3768 > aLong3769)
		{
			sleep((aLong3768 - aLong3769) / 1000000L);
			aLong3770 += aLong3768 - aLong3769;
			aLong3769 += aLong3768 - aLong3769;
			aLong3768 += l;
			return 1;
		}
		int i1 = 0;
		do
		{
			aLong3768 += l;
			++i1;
		}
		while (i1 < 10 && aLong3768 < aLong3769);
		if (aLong3769 > aLong3768)
			aLong3768 = aLong3769;

		return i1;
	}

	private static long calc()
	{
		long l = System.nanoTime();
		{
			long l1 = l - aLong3770;
			aLong3770 = l;
			if (l1 > -5000000000L && l1 < 5000000000L)
			{
				aLongArray3771[anInt3772] = l1;
				anInt3772 = (anInt3772 + 1) % 10;
				if (anInt3773 < 1)
					anInt3773++;

			}
		}
		l = 0L;
		for (int j = 1; j <= anInt3773; ++j)
			l += aLongArray3771[(10 + anInt3772 - j) % 10];

		return l / (long) anInt3773;
	}

	static void push()
	{
		if (aLong3768 > aLong3769)
			aLong3769 += aLong3768 - aLong3769;

		aLong3770 = 0L;
	}

	private static void sleep(long l)
	{
		if (l < 1L)
			return;

		if (l % 10L == 0L)
		{
			try
			{
				Thread.sleep(l - 1L);
			}
			catch (InterruptedException n) { }
			try
			{
				Thread.sleep(1L);
			}
			catch (InterruptedException n) { }
			return;
		}
		try
		{
			Thread.sleep(l);
		}
		catch (InterruptedException n) { }
	}

	private static int anInt3772;
	private static int anInt3773;
	private static long aLong3768;
	private static long aLong3769;
	private static long aLong3770;
	private static long[] aLongArray3771;

	static
	{
		anInt3773 = 1;
		aLongArray3771 = new long[10];
		aLong3769 = System.nanoTime();
		aLong3768 = System.nanoTime();
	}
}

Which is not fully refactored from the rs2 client, but I havent rethought of the proper names since i did this last around 4 months ago.
[/quote]

The client does not use current system time for anything accurate so to change that without a performance increase seems to be rather redundant. If the client required the current system time for something very accurate the nanosecond would be well worth it.[/quote]
The FPS processor uses it mainly to tell how much time has passed…[br][br][size=1]Posted on: November 20, 2009, 07:41:12 am[/size][hr]Take for instance, the flame processor.

long l1 = System.currentTimeMillis();
int k = (int)(l1 - l) / 10 - j;
j = 40 - k;
if (j < 5)
	j = 5;
i = 0;
l = l1;

if you where to set the time back idk… a month? This is what the math would look like:

//l = 2592000000 (1 month 30 days)
long l1 = 0;
int k = (int)(0 - 2592000000) / 10 - j;
j = 40 - k;
if (j < 5)
	j = 5;
i = 0;
l = l1;

so this would sleep for about 5 months lol

@zyle1992 wrote:

  1. Why resize the client? The gameframe looks horrible, the resolution is shit, completely fucked up, you see where i’m going with this.
  2. [quote="“Java API”"]currentTimeMillis

public static long currentTimeMillis()

Returns the current time in milliseconds. Note that while the unit of time of the return value is a millisecond, the granularity of the value depends on the underlying operating system and may be larger. For example, many operating systems measure time in units of tens of milliseconds.

See the description of the class Date for a discussion of slight discrepancies that may arise between "computer time" and coordinated universal time (UTC).

Returns:
    the difference, measured in milliseconds, between the current time and midnight, January 1, 1970 UTC.
See Also:
    Date[/quote]

[quote="“Java API”"]nanoTime

public static long nanoTime()

Returns the current value of the most precise available system timer, in nanoseconds.

This method can only be used to measure elapsed time and is not related to any other notion of system or wall-clock time. The value returned represents nanoseconds since some fixed but arbitrary time (perhaps in the future, so values may be negative). This method provides nanosecond precision, but not necessarily nanosecond accuracy. No guarantees are made about how frequently values change. Differences in successive calls that span greater than approximately 292 years (263 nanoseconds) will not accurately compute elapsed time due to numerical overflow.

For example, to measure how long some code takes to execute:

   long startTime = System.nanoTime();
   // ... the code being measured ...
   long estimatedTime = System.nanoTime() - startTime;
 

Returns:
    The current value of the system timer, in nanoseconds.
Since:
    1.5[/quote]
  1. I tried both of your codes. Both gave me the same answer(approximately. Rounded to make space), so i believe you sir are the one who is misinformed.
